description: The AMDAL public hearing functions as a performative moment of environmental legitimacy. Local leaders, media, and NGOs may attend, and the hearing chair signals formal inclusion of affected communities.
Village-level blessing ceremonies or informal consent meetings serve as ritualized approvals. These events are not legal prerequisites but often dictate whether the project can physically proceed.

When a permit is issued by Denpasar PUPR under mayoral instruction, it is often framed publicly as a strategic investment initiative — anchoring institutional support beyond the project’s technical merit.
The issuance of the IUJPTL license from MEMR signals a project’s transformation into a formal, state-recognized energy actor — anchoring legal identity and system trustworthiness.
The SLO certificate functions not only as a safety pass but as a symbolic rite of passage: the BESS becomes part of the national grid and is formally authorized to deliver value.
